title: 針對律政司鄭若驊之攻擊：請加拿大人幫幫手！

replies.msg:
請加拿大人幫忙，廣發給當地朋友

To our Canadian friends,

I am sure if you have watched the news recently, you may probably be aware of the developing political crisis in Hong Kong, where the pro-Beijing government is trying to introduce a highly controversial extradition bill that will severely undermine fundamental human rights, under which Hong Kong citizens may be deported to China on political crimes and face a judicial system that is opaque and rules arbitrarily applied. Disturbing images and videos of police brutality on peaceful protesters of this bill were already shown around the world, that drew outrage and widespread criticism, but this did not cause the Hong Kong government to back down and Hong Kong’s future still hangs in the balance.

One of the perpetrators of this bill, Secretary for Justice Teresa Yeuk-Wah Cheng, is actually a naturalized Canadian citizen. While it is too early to call for revocation of her Canadian citizenship for committing crimes against humanity, there is still something that can be done to make her alter her stance, and this is where Hong Kong’s people may need your help.

The area we need to focus on is whether Cheng may owe taxes to the Canadian government, particularly during the period when she has returned to Hong Kong to work and declared her non-residency status in Canada. During this period, if she or her husband Otto Lok-To Poon still owned any properties in Canada, or had any financial investments (except RRSP), or owned any businesses under sole-proprietorship or in any partnership capacities, then she may be liable for offshore taxes. If you know, or know someone who might know, on any of the above information, such as where Cheng or Poon may still own, or had owned properties, or any past or existing business relationships and transactions in Canada, then this might be sufficient grounds to open a case with the CRA, so investigative actions can commence. If you work as a real estate agent, or in a bank, there could be just a slim chance you might discover something.

下續...

Persons who report offshore tax evasion cases to the CRA that lead to successful collection of unpaid taxes in excess of $100,000 may be eligible for financial rewards.

https://www.canada.ca/en/revenue-agency/programs/about-canada-revenue-agency-cra/compliance/offshore-tax-informant-program.html

It is not the intention of Hong Kong people to do this for the purpose of gaining financial rewards, but we hope that this incentive will prompt our Canadian friends to help us, as the consequences are dire for the many Canadians living or doing business in Hong Kong should the passage of this bill become successful and written into law.

Thanks in advance for your help!

Yours truly,
2 million+1 concerned Hong Kong citizens
我冇野講
